moves.1. e4: Here's a recent win in the League: not many of those to choose from recently :-(
moves.3... d6: The Steinitz Defence, not one I meet very often.
moves.4. d4: The most aggressive continuation, threatening to win the pinned Nc6.
moves.4... exd4 5. Nxd4: Now the double attack threatens to win a pawn.
moves.5... Bd7: ...easily countered with Black's standard developing move.
moves.6. O-O Nf6 7. Re1 Be7 8. Nc3: With the d-pawn already gone and the B not having been pushed back to a4 yet, I don't see any need for the slower 8. c3 and 9. Nd2 so typical of other Ruy Lopez lines.  This N is looking at leaping to d5 and thence either c7 or e7, depending on the opportunities available.
moves.8... O-O 9. Bf4: First I look to complete my development, contesting control of e5.
moves.9... Nxd4 10. Qxd4: Black's swap off relieves his cramp but White has even more central control.  The Queen seems comfortable here.
moves.10... Bxb5 11. Nxb5 a6 12. Nc3 Qd7 13. R: ? seems to lose a tempo while allowing White time to give his K room to breathe
moves.15... Rfe8 16. c4 Rad8 17. Nxe7+ Rxe7 18: pinning the N against the Rooks
moves.18... Re6 19. f4 Rde8: answering the frontal assault by doubling his rooks
moves.20. Bxf6: To reduce the force attacking e4
moves.23. Qd5 Qb6: Pinning the Rook and threatening the pawn on b2
at last I can push back against Black's threats
moves.27... cxd6 28. Qxd6 Qxd6 29. Rxd6: Material is still level put the pawns are unbalanced, so there's still the probability of a result
moves.29... e4: Black advances his protected central pawn, making it a passed one
moves.30. Kg1: My King rushes back to try to stop it queening.
moves.30... f5 31. Kf1 g6 32. Ke2 Kf7 33. Ke3: This only encourages White to advance his other queenside pawns
moves.35. b4 Ke7 36. g4: aimed at breaking up Black's impressive chain so that I can attack the stragglers
moves.36... a5 37. a3 Kf7 38. gxf5 gxf5 39. Rh: ? Until recently, I've been avoiding swapping Rooks but now swapping risks giving White the win as Black's King is too far away from his advanced pawns.
moves.41. Rd6: only I didn't think Black's K was far enough away at this point so I continued to avoid the swap.
but now I do, and Black's K is even further from the final battlefield.
moves.44... Kxg7 45. bxa5: Now Black's fate is sealed. The b7 pawn can't stop both my 5th rank pawns.
moves.45... Kf7 46. c6: and Black resigned because he cannot stop one of my pawns.

opening: Ruy Lopez (C62), old Steinitz defence, Nimzovich attack
